content.title: HFpEF Management
content.summary: Evidence-based management of heart failure with preserved ejection fraction
key_points: HFpEF: EF ≥50% with symptoms and elevated filling pressures
SGLT2 inhibitors: first drugs to show benefit (EMPEROR-Preserved, DELIVER)
Diuretics for congestion - cornerstone of symptom management
Aggressive comorbidity management: HTN, AF, obesity, diabetes
ARBs and MRAs may reduce hospitalizations
Exercise training improves quality of life

statement.text: HFpEF management centers on SGLT2 inhibitors (Class 2a recommendation), diuretics for congestion, and aggressive management of comorbidities (hypertension, atrial fibrillation, obesity, diabetes, coronary disease). Unlike HFrEF, traditional neurohormonal agents have not demonstrated mortality benefit until SGLT2 inhibitors.
statement.formal: HFpEF Management = SGLT2i + Diuretics + Comorbidity control (HTN, AF, obesity, DM) + Exercise

explanation.intuition: HFpEF is fundamentally different from HFrEF - the heart squeezes normally but doesn't relax properly, leading to high filling pressures. Since the problem isn't contractile failure, drugs that help HFrEF (which target neurohormonal activation of systolic dysfunction) mostly don't help HFpEF.
explanation.key_insight: SGLT2 inhibitors represent a paradigm shift - they're the first drugs to reduce HF hospitalizations in HFpEF. Their mechanism may involve improved cardiac energetics, reduced preload/afterload, and anti-inflammatory effects rather than pure neurohormonal blockade.

definitions_glossary.HFpEF: Heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (EF ≥50%); formerly called diastolic HF
definitions_glossary.diastolic_dysfunction: Impaired ventricular relaxation and compliance causing elevated filling pressures
definitions_glossary.filling_pressures: Left atrial and LV end-diastolic pressures; elevated in HFpEF
definitions_glossary.E_e_prime_ratio: Echocardiographic measure of filling pressures; E/e' >14 suggests elevated LAP
definitions_glossary.BNP: B-type natriuretic peptide; elevated with wall stress from volume/pressure overload
definitions_glossary.NT_proBNP: N-terminal proBNP; more stable than BNP for diagnosis and prognosis
definitions_glossary.concentric_remodeling: Increased wall thickness without chamber dilation; common in HFpEF
definitions_glossary.left_atrial_enlargement: LA dilation from chronically elevated filling pressures
definitions_glossary.pulmonary_venous_congestion: Elevated LA pressure causing pulmonary edema
definitions_glossary.HFpEF_phenotypes: Distinct subtypes: obese, elderly, AF-predominant, CAD-predominant, etc.
definitions_glossary.GLP1_receptor_agonist: Glucagon-like peptide-1 agonist; emerging therapy for HFpEF with obesity
definitions_glossary.exercise_training: Supervised physical activity program improving HFpEF symptoms and function

pathophysiology.mechanism: Impaired LV relaxation and increased passive stiffness → elevated LV filling pressures → pulmonary congestion. Often associated with concentric remodeling from hypertension. Multiple comorbidities (obesity, AF, diabetes) contribute to syndrome.

filling_pressure_evidence: Elevated PCWP on RHC (≥15 mmHg at rest or ≥25 with exercise)

symptomatic_management.diuretics: Loop diuretics for congestion; adjust to euvolemia
symptomatic_management.exercise: Supervised exercise training improves quality of life and functional capacity

comorbidity_management.hypertension: Aggressive BP control (<130/80); ARBs, CCBs preferred
comorbidity_management.atrial_fibrillation: Rate control (beta-blockers, non-DHP CCBs); anticoagulation for stroke prevention
comorbidity_management.obesity: Weight loss improves symptoms; GLP-1 agonists emerging
comorbidity_management.diabetes: SGLT2 inhibitors for dual HF and glucose benefit

uncertain_benefit.MRAs: TOPCAT: possible benefit in Americas but not Russia; may reduce hospitalizations
uncertain_benefit.ARBs: CHARM-Preserved: borderline hospitalization reduction, no mortality benefit

definition.@value: Evidence-based approach to managing heart failure with preserved ejection fraction, emphasizing SGLT2 inhibitors, diuretics, and comorbidity control

medicalCode.description: Heart failure with preserved ejection fraction

learning_objectives: Define HFpEF diagnostic criteria including filling pressure evidence
Explain why traditional HFrEF drugs fail in HFpEF
Describe SGLT2 inhibitor evidence in HFpEF
clinical_pearls: Elevated E/e' and LA enlargement support HFpEF diagnosis when BNP is borderline
Obesity is both cause and consequence - weight loss helps symptoms
SGLT2 inhibitors work regardless of diabetes status
AF is both marker of severity and therapeutic target
